bibl.title: Letter from John R. Taylor to Philip Showalter Hench, February 5, 1942

div1.p: Taylor comments on Sternberg's yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from John R. Taylor to Philip Showalter Hench, February 5, 1942
div1.opener:
Dr Phillip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester. Minn.
548 Grand Ave
Upper Darby. P. a.
Feb 5th 1942
Dear Dr Hench
div1.p:
Your letter of Feb 2, received. No hurry about
return of photographs I sent, you may keep them as long as necessary,
I now realize what you inferred by colleagues, I suppose those
who were connected with me at Las Animas and other places,
however, will hold that matter until I receive your questions
as some details of persons and acts may be necessary. Will
then have some idea as to the subjects you propose to cover.

The bibliography of the history of yellow fever is
enormous, and it is possible that I may be able to refer
you to some that I do not possess, that is along your
proposed lines.

Am familiar with the work of Forbes and
Lambert whom you mention, and hope you were able to
get information.

It is possible I could suggest some data that
should be included in your article, but hesitate to
do so, because you know what you propose to cover,
and I don't, However, will suggest one;-

It would appear to me that Sternberg should
have been included in your first article, and still
think mention of him should be made in your second.

Sternberg for many years previous to 1900, had
been one of the leading American authorities on
the subject of yellow fever and had made laborious
2
2
investigations as to its cause, in Havana, Brazil and Mexico.
Sternberg was the man who appointed the Reed Commission
and gave them orders what they were to do when they were sent
to Cuba.

“The exhaustive reports of
Chailé in 1880 and by Sternberg in 1890 must always stand
as monuments to the earnest spirit of investigation with which
the work (causative factors)Taylor was pursued.”

Of course we know that his many years of work in
the study of yellow fever, failed to discover its cause,
but that should not be held against him. Apart from
his being the leading bacteri American bacteriologist
of his time, he was undoubtedly a yellow fever expert.

I mentioned in a previous letter about photos of Camp
Lazear, and suggested two pictures in the article “Health
Heroes” by Hallack and Turner, however, I think these
were copied from Kelly's book on Reed, because
in Kelleys book are two very good photographs
of two buildings in Camp Lazear. You will be
able to get the negatives from the publishers.
Hope you have been able to obtain photos
of Columbia Barracks as you desire.
